title: MVP KanjiReader - Japanese Kanji Learning App
description:
# KanjiReader MVP

## Vision
Transform passive Japanese consumption (reading, watching) into active learning. Help learners SEE, HEAR, and UNDERSTAND Japanese characters in context.

## Problem
Translation tools show English meanings but don't teach Kanji recognition or pronunciation. Users understand content but never learn to read Japanese independently.

## Solution
Mobile app that:
1. Captures/uploads images of Japanese text
2. OCR identifies Kanji, Hiragana, Katakana
3. Segments text into words (not characters - meanings change with context)
4. Provides pronunciation via TTS
5. Shows romaji + English meanings

## Target User
Avinash - Developer learning Japanese, has ADHD (needs quick interactions, minimal friction)

## Tech Stack
- React Native + Expo (managed workflow)
- Google Cloud Vision API (OCR)
- Jisho API (dictionary)
- Expo Speech (TTS - primary, free, offline)
- Zustand (state management)

## Platform
- Primary: iOS (iPhone)
- Secondary: Android
- Distribution: Local install only (TestFlight/.ipa/.apk)

## Key Decisions
- Word-level display (not character-level) - Kanji meanings change with words
- Full text visible in results - see complete sentence
- Expo Speech primary - free, no API costs, works offline
- No region selection MVP - full capture, smart OCR
- Cache for performance, not full offline mode

## Success Criteria
- Full flow works: capture → OCR → segment → display → pronounce
- App installs on physical iPhone/Android
- Japanese pronunciation is clear and correct
- ADHD-friendly: quick interactions, immediate feedback

## References
- openspec/changes/mvp-kanji-reader/proposal.md
- openspec/changes/mvp-kanji-reader/tasks.md
- openspec/specs/*.md

title: Phase 1: Project Setup & Foundation
description:
# Phase 1: Project Setup & Foundation

## Purpose
Establish the foundational structure for the KanjiReader app. This phase MUST complete before any feature development begins.

## Why This Matters
- Proper project structure prevents tech debt accumulation
- TypeScript + ESLint catch bugs early
- Base components ensure UI consistency
- EAS configuration enables device testing

## Deliverables
1. Expo project with TypeScript
2. Folder structure (src/, components/, services/, etc.)
3. ESLint + Prettier configuration
4. Base UI components (Button, Card, Loading, ErrorBoundary)
5. Theme system (colors, typography)
6. EAS Build profiles for local distribution
7. Environment variable setup

## Technical Decisions
- Expo managed workflow (not bare) - faster iteration, easier camera access
- pnpm for package management
- Zustand for state (simpler than Redux for ADHD-friendly codebase)
- TypeScript strict mode

## Dependencies
None - this is the foundation.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] App runs in Expo Go
- [ ] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [ ] ESLint passes with zero warnings
- [ ] Base components render correctly
- [ ] EAS builds successfully for iOS and Android

title: Initialize Expo Project with TypeScript
description:
# Initialize Expo Project

## Task
Create new Expo project using TypeScript template.

## Commands
```bash
npx create-expo-app@latest kanji-reader --template blank-typescript
cd kanji-reader
```

## Folder Structure to Create
```
src/
├── components/     # Reusable UI components
├── screens/        # Screen components
├── services/       # API/business logic
├── hooks/          # Custom React hooks
├── utils/          # Helper functions
├── types/          # TypeScript types
├── constants/      # App constants
└── store/          # Zustand stores
assets/             # Images, fonts
```

## Why This Structure
- Separation of concerns
- Easy to navigate for ADHD brain
- Scales well as app grows
- Common React Native convention

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Expo project created
- [ ] TypeScript configured
- [ ] Folder structure in place
- [ ] App runs with 'npx expo start'

title: Configure ESLint and Prettier
description:
# Configure Linting & Formatting

## Task
Set up ESLint and Prettier for consistent code quality.

## Packages to Install
```bash
pnpm add -D eslint prettier eslint-config-expo eslint-plugin-react-hooks @typescript-eslint/parser @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin
```

## Configuration Files
- .eslintrc.js - ESLint rules
- .prettierrc - Prettier formatting
- .eslintignore - Exclude node_modules, build

## Key Rules
- React Hooks rules enabled
- TypeScript strict checks
- Single quotes, no semicolons (preference)
- 2-space indentation

## Why This Matters
- Consistent code style across all files
- Catches bugs before runtime
- Makes code reviews easier
- Reduces cognitive load when reading code

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] ESLint runs without errors
- [ ] Prettier formats all files
- [ ] VS Code integration works
- [ ] Pre-commit hook optional

title: Set up Environment Variables
description:
# Environment Variables Setup

## Task
Configure environment variables for API keys and config.

## Packages
```bash
pnpm add expo-constants
```

## Files to Create
- .env.example (template, committed)
- .env (actual values, gitignored)
- src/constants/config.ts (typed access)

## Variables Needed
```
GOOGLE_CLOUD_VISION_API_KEY=xxx
# Future: GOOGLE_CLOUD_TTS_API_KEY=xxx (v2)
```

## Why
- Keep secrets out of code
- Easy to switch between dev/prod
- Required for Google Cloud Vision OCR

## Security Note
.env MUST be in .gitignore - never commit API keys.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] .env.example exists with placeholders
- [ ] .env is gitignored
- [ ] Config module provides typed access
- [ ] App reads env vars correctly

title: Create Theme System
description:
# Theme System

## Task
Create consistent design tokens and theme provider.

## Files
- src/constants/colors.ts
- src/constants/typography.ts
- src/constants/spacing.ts
- src/context/ThemeContext.tsx (optional for dark mode later)

## Color Palette
```typescript
export const colors = {
  // Character type colors (core to app identity)
  kanji: '#3B82F6',      // Blue
  hiragana: '#10B981',   // Green
  katakana: '#F59E0B',   // Orange
  romaji: '#6B7280',     // Gray
  
  // UI colors
  primary: '#3B82F6',
  background: '#FFFFFF',
  surface: '#F3F4F6',
  text: '#1F2937',
  textSecondary: '#6B7280',
  error: '#EF4444',
  success: '#10B981',
}
```

## Typography
- Font: System default (fastest load)
- Sizes: 12, 14, 16, 20, 24, 32
- Japanese text needs larger sizes for readability

## Why These Colors
- Character type colors are THE learning signal
- Blue/green/orange easily distinguishable
- Consistent with proposal.md decisions

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Colors exported and typed
- [ ] Typography scale defined
- [ ] Spacing scale defined (4, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32)
- [ ] Used consistently across components

title: Create Base UI Components
description:
# Base UI Components

## Task
Build reusable foundational components for consistent UI.

## Components to Create

### Button (src/components/Button.tsx)
- Primary and secondary variants
- Loading state with spinner
- Disabled state
- Full-width option
- Haptic feedback on press

### Card (src/components/Card.tsx)
- Elevated surface with shadow
- Pressable variant (for WordCard later)
- Selected state styling

### Loading (src/components/Loading.tsx)
- Full-screen loading overlay
- Inline loading indicator
- Shimmer/skeleton variant

### ErrorBoundary (src/components/ErrorBoundary.tsx)
- Catches render errors
- Shows friendly error message
- Retry button
- Logs error for debugging

## Design Principles
- ADHD-friendly: Clear visual feedback
- Touch targets: Minimum 44x44 points
- Consistent with theme colors

## Why Base Components First
- Ensures UI consistency from start
- Faster feature development
- Single source of truth for styling

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All 4 components created
- [ ] TypeScript props properly typed
- [ ] Uses theme colors/spacing
- [ ] Basic tests pass

title: Configure EAS Build for Local Distribution
description:
# EAS Build Configuration

## Task
Set up Expo Application Services (EAS) for building installable apps.

## Why EAS
- Official Expo build service
- Handles iOS signing complexity
- Free tier sufficient for personal use
- Outputs .ipa (iOS) and .apk (Android)

## Setup Steps
```bash
# Install EAS CLI
npm install -g eas-cli

# Login to Expo
eas login

# Initialize EAS in project
eas init

# Create eas.json
```

## eas.json Configuration
```json
{
  "build": {
    "development": {
      "developmentClient": true,
      "distribution": "internal"
    },
    "preview": {
      "distribution": "internal",
      "ios": {
        "simulator": false
      }
    },
    "production": {
      "distribution": "internal"
    }
  }
}
```

## iOS Specific
- Requires Apple Developer account (9/year)
- Ad-hoc provisioning for local install
- Register device UDIDs

## Android Specific
- No account needed for .apk
- Enable 'Unknown sources' to install

## Test Commands
```bash
eas build --platform ios --profile preview
eas build --platform android --profile preview
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] eas.json configured
- [ ] iOS build succeeds
- [ ] Android build succeeds
- [ ] Can install on physical devices
